slides.title: Welcome to Microbiology
slides.content:
# Introduction to Microbiology & Biotechnology

Welcome to **Microbiology** - the study of microscopic life!

## What You Will Learn:
- **Bacteria** - Prokaryotic microbes
- **Viruses** - Non-living pathogens
- **Fungi and Protists** - Eukaryotic microbes
- **Biotechnology** - Using organisms for benefit

> **Fun Fact:** There are more bacteria in your body than human cells!

## Types of Microorganisms:

| Group | Cell Type | Examples |
|-------|-----------|----------|
| Bacteria | Prokaryotic | E. coli, Streptococcus |
| Archaea | Prokaryotic | Methanogens |
| Fungi | Eukaryotic | Yeast, mold |
| Protists | Eukaryotic | Amoeba, algae |
| Viruses | Non-cellular | HIV, influenza |

slides.title: Bacteria
slides.content:
# Bacteria

**Prokaryotes** - no membrane-bound nucleus

## Structure:

| Part | Function |
|------|----------|
| Cell wall | Protection, shape |
| Cell membrane | Selective barrier |
| Cytoplasm | Cell contents |
| Ribosome | Protein synthesis |
| Nucleoid | DNA region |
| Plasmid | Extra circular DNA |
| Flagella | Movement |
| Pili | Attachment, transfer |

## Shapes:
- **Coccus:** Spherical
- **Bacillus:** Rod-shaped
- **Spirillum:** Spiral

## Gram Staining:

| Type | Cell Wall | Color |
|------|-----------|-------|
| Gram-positive | Thick peptidoglycan | Purple |
| Gram-negative | Thin + outer membrane | Pink |

## Reproduction:
- Binary fission (asexual)
- Can double every 20 minutes
- Genetic variation through conjugation, transformation, transduction

## Importance:
- Decomposition
- Nitrogen fixation
- Gut flora
- Disease (pathogens)

slides.title: Viruses
slides.content:
# Viruses

**Not considered living** - cannot reproduce independently

## Structure:
- Genetic material (DNA or RNA)
- Protein coat (capsid)
- Some have envelope (lipid layer)

## Characteristics:
- Obligate intracellular parasites
- Host-specific
- Much smaller than bacteria

## Viral Replication:

### Lytic Cycle:
1. Attachment to host cell
2. Entry (injection of DNA/RNA)
3. Replication of viral components
4. Assembly of new viruses
5. Lysis (cell bursts)

### Lysogenic Cycle:
1. Viral DNA integrates into host genome
2. Replicated with host DNA
3. Can later enter lytic cycle

## Types of Viruses:

| Genetic Material | Examples |
|------------------|----------|
| DNA | Herpes, smallpox |
| RNA | Influenza, HIV |
| Retrovirus | HIV (RNA -> DNA) |

## Control:
- Vaccines (prevention)
- Antivirals (treatment)
- No antibiotics work on viruses

slides.title: Fungi and Protists
slides.content:
# Fungi and Protists

## Fungi:

**Eukaryotes** with cell walls (chitin)

**Types:**
- Yeasts (single-celled)
- Molds (multicellular, filamentous)
- Mushrooms (fruiting bodies)

**Structure:**
- Hyphae (filaments)
- Mycelium (network of hyphae)

**Characteristics:**
- Heterotrophs (absorb nutrients)
- Decomposers
- Some parasites, some mutualistic

**Examples:**
- Bread yeast (Saccharomyces)
- Penicillium (antibiotics)
- Athlete's foot (pathogen)

## Protists:

Diverse group of eukaryotes.

| Type | Mode | Examples |
|------|------|----------|
| Protozoa | Heterotroph | Amoeba, Paramecium |
| Algae | Autotroph | Diatoms, kelp |
| Slime molds | Decomposer | Physarum |

**Movement:**
- Cilia (Paramecium)
- Flagella (Euglena)
- Pseudopods (Amoeba)

**Importance:**
- Produce O2 (algae)
- Base of aquatic food webs
- Some cause disease (malaria)

slides.title: Disease and Immunity
slides.content:
# Microbial Disease

## Pathogens:

| Type | Examples | Treatment |
|------|----------|----------|
| Bacteria | Tuberculosis, strep | Antibiotics |
| Virus | Flu, COVID | Antivirals, vaccines |
| Fungi | Ringworm | Antifungals |
| Protozoa | Malaria | Antiparasitics |

## Transmission:

- Direct contact
- Airborne (droplets)
- Waterborne
- Vector (mosquitoes, ticks)
- Contaminated food

## Koch's Postulates:
1. Microbe found in all disease cases
2. Isolated and grown in pure culture
3. Causes disease when introduced to healthy host
4. Same microbe re-isolated

## Antibiotics:

**Mode of action:**
- Inhibit cell wall synthesis
- Disrupt protein synthesis
- Interfere with DNA replication

**Resistance:**
- Overuse promotes resistance
- MRSA, superbugs
- Need new antibiotics

## Prevention:
- Vaccination
- Hygiene
- Sanitation
- Food safety

slides.title: Biotechnology Basics
slides.content:
# Biotechnology

**Using organisms to make products or solve problems**

## Traditional Biotechnology:

| Product | Organism |
|---------|----------|
| Bread | Yeast |
| Beer/Wine | Yeast |
| Yogurt | Bacteria |
| Cheese | Bacteria, fungi |

## Modern Biotechnology:

### Recombinant DNA:
1. Cut gene (restriction enzymes)
2. Insert into vector (plasmid)
3. Transform into host (bacteria)
4. Express gene, make product

### Applications:

| Field | Application |
|-------|-------------|
| Medicine | Insulin, vaccines |
| Agriculture | GM crops |
| Industry | Enzymes |
| Environment | Bioremediation |

## Gene Cloning:
- Make many copies of gene
- Study gene function
- Produce proteins

## Genetic Engineering:
- Add/remove/modify genes
- Create transgenic organisms
- Gene therapy for diseases

slides.title: Biotech Quiz
slides.quizQuestion: What is used to cut DNA at specific sites?

slides.title: Applications
slides.content:
# Biotechnology Applications

## Medicine:

**Recombinant products:**
- Human insulin (for diabetes)
- Growth hormone
- Clotting factors
- Vaccines

**Gene therapy:**
- Insert functional genes
- Treat genetic diseases

## Agriculture:

**GM Crops:**
- Pest resistance (Bt crops)
- Herbicide tolerance
- Enhanced nutrition (Golden Rice)
- Drought resistance

**Concerns:**
- Environmental impact
- Food safety
- Labeling

## Industry:

**Enzymes:**
- Laundry detergents
- Food processing
- Biofuels

**Bioremediation:**
- Clean up oil spills
- Treat wastewater
- Remove pollutants

## Forensics:

**DNA fingerprinting:**
- Crime scenes
- Paternity testing
- Identification

slides.title: Summary
slides.content:
# Microbiology & Biotechnology Summary

## Microorganisms:

| Type | Cell Type | Example |
|------|-----------|--------|
| Bacteria | Prokaryote | E. coli |
| Archaea | Prokaryote | Methanogens |
| Fungi | Eukaryote | Yeast |
| Protists | Eukaryote | Amoeba |
| Viruses | Non-cellular | Influenza |

## Viruses:
- Not living
- Need host to reproduce
- Lytic vs lysogenic cycle

## Disease:
- Pathogens cause disease
- Antibiotics for bacteria only
- Vaccines prevent infection

## Biotechnology:
- Recombinant DNA technology
- Gene cloning
- GMOs
- Applications in medicine, agriculture, industry

## Key Tools:
- Restriction enzymes (cut)
- Ligase (join)
- Plasmids (vectors)
- PCR (amplify)

> **Congratulations!** You've completed Microbiology & Biotechnology!
